de.esoco.lib.datatype

Class DateRange

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.esoco.lib.datatype.DateRange
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Comparable<DateRange>

    public class DateRange
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Comparable<DateRange>, java.io.Serializable
    Immutable datatype that describes date ranges. It is encoded with two dates that contain the start and end of the date range. The end date will be exclusive, i.e. it will be 1 millisecond AFTER the end of the date range and on the first millisecond of the adjacent range.

    Date ranges are comparable based on their position in time (not their size in milliseconds). A range is considered to be "larger" if it's end date is after that of another range and "smaller" if the end date is before that of the other range. If the end dates are equal the start dates are consider accordingly. That also means that a range that is fully contained in another is always considered smaller. Comparing may not be sufficient for all cases so application code should also use the methods contains(DateRange) and overlaps(DateRange) for final decisions if necessary.

    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Constructor Detail

      • DateRange

        public DateRange(java.util.Date rStart,
                 java.util.Date rEnd)
        Creates a new DateRange object that is valid from a certain start date until a certain end date. If the end date is NULL the range will be open, i.e. the method isValid() will not check against an end date.

        This constructor makes defensive copies of the mutable Date arguments so that later changes to these objects won't affect the internal state of this instance.

        Parameters:
        rStart - The start date of the range (inclusive)
        rEnd - The end date of the range (inclusive) or NULL for no end

      • DateRange

        public DateRange(java.util.Calendar rStart,
                 java.util.Calendar rEnd)
        Creates a new DateRange object that is valid from a certain start date until a certain end date, defined as java.util.Calendar instances. If the end date is NULL the range will be open, i.e. the method isValid() will not check against an end date.
        Parameters:
        rStart - A Calendar instance containing the start date of the range (inclusive)
        rEnd - A Calendar instance containing the end date of the range (inclusive) or NULL for no end
        See Also:
        DateRange(Date, Date)

      • DateRange

        public DateRange(java.time.Instant rStart,
                 java.time.Instant rEnd)
        Creates a new instance from Instants.
        Parameters:
        rStart - The start instant
        rEnd - The end instant (exclusive)

      • DateRange

        public DateRange(long nStartMillis,
                 long nEndMillis)
        Creates a new DateRange object from the milliseconds of it's start and end dates. The milliseconds are counted from the start date January 1, 1970, 00:00:00 GMT.
        Parameters:
        nStartMillis - The milliseconds of the start time
        nEndMillis - The milliseconds of the end time
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If start > end

                                     DateRange.StandardDateRange eStandardRange)
        Calculates a date range for a standard date range relative to a given date.
        Parameters:

      • calculateFor

        public static DateRange calculateFor(java.util.Date rDate,
                                     de.esoco.lib.datatype.Period rPeriod)

        Parameters:
        rDate - The date to place the date range around
        rPeriod - The period to calculate
        Returns:
        The resulting date range

      • compareTo

        public int compareTo(DateRange rOther)
        Compares this date ranges with another. The comparison is relative to the position in time, not to the "size" of the date range. The algorithm used is:
        1. If the end dates are not equal, return the comparison of the end dates
        2. Else return the comparison of the start dates
        Specified by:
        compareTo in interface java.lang.Comparable<DateRange>
        Parameters:
        rOther - The other DateRange object to compare with
        See Also:
        Comparable.compareTo(Object)

      • contains

        public boolean contains(java.util.Date rDate)
        To check if this date range contains a certain date. Returns TRUE if the argument lies between this range's start and end dates. The end date is exclusive, i.e. it will be 1 millisecond AFTER the actual end of the date range and on the first millisecond of the adjacent range.
        Parameters:
        rDate - The date to test against this range
        Returns:
        TRUE, if start <= rDate <= end

      • contains

        public boolean contains(DateRange rRange)
        To check if this date range completely contains another range. Returns TRUE if the arguments start and end dates lie between this range's start and end dates. The end date is exclusive, i.e. it will be 1 millisecond AFTER the end of the date range and on the first millisecond of the adjacent range.
        Parameters:
        rRange - The range to test against this range
        Returns:
        TRUE, if start <= rRange.start and end >= rRange.end

      • equals

        public boolean equals(java.lang.Object rObj)
        Test for equality with another object. Returns true if the argument is also a DateRange object and compareTo(rObj) returns 0.
        Overrides:
        equals in class java.lang.Object
        Parameters:
        rObj - The object to compare with for equality
        Returns:
        TRUE if the objects are equal

      • getEnd

        public java.util.Date getEnd()
        Returns the end date of the date range.
        Returns:
        A new instance of java.util.Date containing the end date

      • getStart

        public java.util.Date getStart()
        Returns the start date of the date range.
        Returns:
        A new instance of java.util.Date containing the start date

      • hashCode

        public int hashCode()
        Calculates and returns the hash code for this range.
        Overrides:
        hashCode in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        A hash code based on the internal start and end date values

      • overlaps

        public boolean overlaps(DateRange rOther)
        To check if this date range overlaps with another range. Returns TRUE if at least either the arguments start or end date lies between this range's start and end dates. The end date is exclusive, i.e. it will be 1 millisecond AFTER the end of the date range and on the first millisecond of the adjacent range.
        Parameters:
        rOther - The range to test against this range
        Returns:
        TRUE, if NOT (rRange.end < start OR rRange.start > end)
        See Also:
        contains(DateRange)

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
